review_title: Great community college to work for
job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Community college employers have a notorious past and current history of exploiting labor. Relatively speaking, Santa Monica College is one of the exceptions. The administration cares more about the instructors than those at other place(s) that I have worked for.
cons: Community colleges is a system that exploits labor. Even though the admins seem to care, they are constrained by the system for whatever reason. It's probably a mixture of inertia and apathy. Being an outsider (to the admin leadership circle), I can't so for sure what is the real cause. They (the admins) do say the right words, and often seem (at least formally) to do what they can for the workers.

job_title: Disabled Student Services Assistant in Santa Monica, CA
pros: Great Benefits, Stellar Job security.
cons: 1. Hard to further your career as departments tend to higher in-house. 2.They will put the needs of faculty before classified staff. For example, during the main COVID outbreak in 2020, classified staff were partially furloughed and at risk of potential layoffs while faculty received a COVID stipend and other perks.

review_title: A nice place to work, if you can stay there
job_title: Adjunct Faculty Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
The students at Santa Monica College are more motivated on average than community college students that I've taught at other schools. Working with them is delightful.
The pay is excellent for adjunct work, especially at a community college.
FT colleagues are friendly and welcoming to adjuncts.
The campus is beautiful.
Hiring is straightforward and HR is helpful.
Training for classroom technology is great.
cons:
The same issues with adjunct work everywhere apply here - no consistent work from semester to semester = no job security, even when students love your classes. 

There are only three or four days to notify interest for fall classes in the spring once a notice asking for interest goes out. Notices go only to your SMC account, even if you no longer teach there and only check SMC email once or twice a week, which makes it easy to miss the very short deadline. This means that finding work there again is challenging if you came to teaching the fall or winter term but were not offered a class for the spring. 

Even if you successfully bid for a class, faculty with more seniority get classes first, making it very likely that you will be hired for one class and not offered one again until they come back to you the next year, at which point you will have had to find other work.

job_title: Administrative Clerk in Santa Monica, CA
pros:
Great medical, dental vision benefits
Attend classes at SMC free, while employed there.
cons:
People on power trips.
The "Merit System" is a CASTE SYSTEM.  It's hard to test out of your present position.  They make you test with the rest of the world, even though you're already working there.  Transfers are set up to ONLY BE A LATERAL MOVE.  So, the Merit System is set up to keep people in one place.

review_title: SMC is great for students, hopefully, it is better now for employees.
job_title: Administrator in Santa Monica, CA
pros:
It is one of the best community colleges in the country. 
The quality of students, and many faculty, is on par with UCs and CSUs. This is why the transfers to four-year institutions are impressive.
The faculty expectations of the students are high, which creates a healthy and challenging learning environment.
cons:
First and foremost, the parking is horrendous. 
Scoring a job there helps if you are married or related to a current employee. You will jump the cue and get the job.
In the past, only yes men and women were hired, pushing out individuals who had given years of their lives to making SMC the college that it is.

review_title: Politics rule the day!  If you are not a person of color watch out.

No equity for adjuncts
